titlestmt.subtitle: An inventory of his cartoons at Syracuse University

list.item: 30 Oct 2009 - added detailed bio, scope and inventory (SK)

did.head: Overview of the Collection
did.abstract: 56 original political cartoons from World War I.

bioghist.head: Biographical History
bioghist.p: [Photo at right: "Slow Asphyxiation" by Louis Raemaekers depicting soldiers who were exposed to irritating gases while fighting in the trenches.]
Louis Raemaekers (1869-1956) was a Dutch painter and cartoonist known for his anti-German cartoons during World War I.
Louis Raemaekers was born in 1869 in Roermond, in the Netherlands. His father was a newspaper editor and his mother was originally from Germany. Raemaekers studied art in Holland and Brussels.

Beginning his career as a painter and illustrator, Raemaekers joined the
Algemeen Handelsblad in 1907 and in 1909 starting drawing for the
De Telegraaf after the
Algemeen Handelsblad became uncomfortable with his strong inclination towards producing anti-German cartoons.

Raemaekers became known for his biting portrayals of the cruelty of war, particularly as brought about by the German military’s actions in Belgium. Germany was outraged by Raemaekers’ works and the Netherlands charged him with endangering the country's neutrality in the war (although he was never convicted) while a bounty was put on him by Kaiser Wilhelm II. Raemaekers' work was well received among allied countries. Raemaekers fled to Britain and was welcomed by British dignitaries and journalists. France presented Raemaekers with the Cross of the Legion of Honour and hosted a reception for him at the Sorbonne. In 1917 he toured the United States and being critical of the United States' neutrality, urged the United States to intervene in the war.

Raemaekers’ cartoons were widely popular throughout the world and heavily reproduced. Some were compiled in books and reprinted as posters and postcards. An estimated 1200 cartoons were reproduced in allied countries and an estimated 1 billion copies were published in the United States during 1917. Several books about the war were published with his cartoons including the 1916 work,
Raemaeker’s Cartoons (1916) and
Raemaeker’s Cartoon History of the War (1919).

During World War I, Raemaekers’ cartoons were exhibited throughout the world including in Spain, Britain, France and the United States and in 1942, he lent works to the “Cartoons of the Day” exhibit at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City. Raemaekers, also critical of widespread fascism and Nazism in the 1930s, ended his career in the early 1940s.
Louis Raemaekers died on July 26, 1956 in Scheveningen, Netherlands.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents of the Collection
scopecontent.p:
The
Louis Raemaekers Cartoons are comprised of 56 original political cartoons from World War I (1914-1918). Many of these cartoons appeared in the book,
Raemaekers' Cartoon History of the War (1919).

Raemaekers used the medium of cartooning to communicate Germany's actions during World War I, particularly against the Belgians to a worldwide audience. Raemaekers was an outspoken critic of Germany and often depicted the war crimes and atrocities the country was alleged to have committed. One theme of interest is Raemaekers' portrayal of Christianity and its relationship to the war.
The cartoons were drawn in charcoal, ink and gouache on illustration board and none bear specific dates.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Collection
arrangement.p: The cartoons have been numbered and are foldered individually.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p:
The book,
Raemaekers' Cartoon History of the War (1919) is available in the &scrc_name; Rare Book collections. Please see
SUMMIT for more information.
&scrc_name; has collections of over one hundred cartoonists. Please refer to &subjindex; for a complete listing.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The majority of our archival and manuscript collections are housed offsite and require advanced notice for retrieval. Researchers are encouraged to contact us in advance concerning the collection material they wish to access for their research.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Due to the fragile nature of these cartoons, users are required to wear gloves when handling the material.
Written permission must be obtained from SCRC and all relevant rights holders before publishing quotations, excerpts or images from any materials in this collection.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Preferred citation for this material is as follows:

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p:
Gift of
Yale University Art Gallery, 1985.

did.abstract: At Rosselaere the German Troops forced the Belgian townsfolk to march in front of them.
"Father, what have we done?"
"Ain't I a lovable fellow?"
"It was I who opened fire on Rheims Cathedral"

did.unittitle: 007.Raemaekers A Letter from the German Trenches.
did.abstract: "We have gained a good bit; our cemeteries now extend as far as the sea."
"We shall never sheath the sword until Belgium recovers all, and more than all she has sacrificed." Mr. Asquith, 9th November, 1914
First Zeppelin raid on Paris
And they bowed the knee before him.
The Yellow Book

did.unittitle: 012.Raemaekers "My son, go and fight for your Motherland!"
did.abstract: {A recruiting poster. Only piece signed by Raemaekers in the collection}
Herod's Night-mare. "Are they crying 'Mother' --or 'Murder'?"
Italy: "Indeed she is my sister."
Bernhardi: "Have we not surpassed your most sanguine expectations?"

did.unittitle: 016.Raemaekers Botha to Britain: "I have carried out everything in accordance with our compact at Vereeniging."

did.abstract: "Well, have you nearly done?"
"If England wins the war, she will never get our Kultur"
At the Labour Congress recently held in England the delegates passed a vote of confidence in the present British Government by a huge majority
Austria: "Hurrah! We have only to leave the countries we have already ransaced."
British Seaman to Labour Pacifist: "Don't you believe, my beauty, that we are going to ship you to them German friends of yours at Stockholm!"
"We are ready now to make peace so that you may enjoy still more the blessings of our Kultur."
480 millions of francs have been imposed as a war tax but soup is given gratis.
Seaman 1: "Do you remember Black Mary of Hamburg?" Seaman 2: "Aye, well" Seaman 1: "She got six years for killing a child, whilst we get the Iron Cross for killing twenty ar Hartlepool."
A new and purer Russia rises like a Phoenix from the ashes of the old reactionary regime.
"Hullo! Postdam? Did you thank your dear old God for this new success?"
War and Hunger: "Now you must accompany us to the end." The Kaiser: "yes to my end.!"

did.unittitle: 031.Raemaekers We wage war on Divine Principles.

did.abstract: The War God: "In 1914 you rejected every suggestion of Peace and insisted on the mailed fist, now it will not let go it's grip, Do you still like it?"
The Dove: "They say they do not want peace as they have time enough." The Eagle: "Alas! That is just what we haven't got."

did.unittitle: 036.Raemaekers William: "Now we will give England the death stroke."
did.abstract: (But observe that he is blind to the character of his Ally's embrace.)
'It's all right, If I hadn't done it someone else might."
"It is a war of Rapine! On that I take my stand, I cannot do otherwise." Liebknecht was the one member who protested against the war.
Belgian workmen were forcibly deported to Germany.

did.unittitle: 040.Raemaekers The Vicory Loan: "And what did you lend, to-day?"

did.abstract: Germany lying in wait for Holland.
The Dutchman: " Down with Milirtarism." The German: " That's right. So much the sooner you will be ours."

did.unittitle: 043.Raemaekers The Final Blow to Prussian Militarism
did.abstract: Hercules slaying the wild Boar.
The Old Frenchman: "our guns come nearer."
"war is an Instrument of progress -- choose the right moment to attack." von Bernhardi, 1912
"We have better luck with passenger boats than with war ships, for they cannot shoot."
"Sire, it's quite easy; for every witness who swears we've murdered innocent people we will produce two who will sewar they did not see it."
William: " How many have you swallowed to day, my faithful friend?"
Belgium. Pillage is expressly prohibited. Article 47 of the Rules of War.

did.unittitle: 053.Raemaekers The Stars and Stripes in the Service of Humanity.

did.abstract: "Since the first days the war has been nothing to us but the defence of our right to existence and freedom. Therefore we were first and alone to declare our readiness for negotiations" Herr von Bethmann Hollweg.

did.unittitle: 055.Raemaekers The very stones cry out "Thou art the man."

did.abstract: English American and Belgian sailors murdered by a U-boat Commander.
